awd_titl_txt: CPS: Synergy: Sensor Network-Based Lower-Limb Prosthetic Optimization and Control
awd_abstract_narration:
More than one million people including many wounded warfighters from recent military missions are living with lower-limb amputation in the United States. This project will design wearable body area sensor systems for real-time measurement of amputee's energy expenditure and will develop computer algorithms for automatic lower-limb prosthesis optimization. The developed technology will offer a practical tool for the optimal prosthetic tuning that may maximally reduce amputee's energy expenditure during walking. Further, this project will develop user-control technology to support user's volitional control of lower-limb prostheses. The developed volitional control technology will allow the prosthesis to be adaptive to altered environments and situations such that amputees can walk as using their own biological limbs. An optimized prosthesis with user-control capability will increase equal force distribution on the intact and prosthetic limbs and decrease the risk of damage to the intact limb from the musculoskeletal imbalance or pathologies. Maintenance of health in these areas is essential for the amputee's quality of life and well-being.  Student participation is supported.

This research will advance Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) science and engineering through the integration of sensor and computational technologies for the optimization and control of physical systems. This project will design body area sensor network systems which integrate spatiotemporal information from electromyography (EMG), electroencephalography (EEG) and inertia measurement unit (IMU) sensors, providing quantitative, real-time measurements of the user's physical load and mental effort for personalized prosthesis optimization. This project will design machine learning technology-based, automatic prosthesis parameter optimization technology to support in-home prosthesis optimization by users themselves. This project will also develop an EEG-based, embedded computing-supported volitional control technology to support user?s volitional control of a prosthesis in real-time by their thoughts to cope with altered situations and environments. The technical advances from this project will provide wearable and wireless body area sensing solutions for broader applications in healthcare and human-CPS interaction applications. The explored computational methods will be broadly applicable for real-time, automatic target recognition from spatiotemporal, multivariate data in CPS-related communication and control applications. This synergic project will be implemented under multidisciplinary team collaboration among computer scientists and engineers, clinicians and prosthetic industry engineers. This project will also provide interdisciplinary, CPS relevant training for both undergraduate and graduate students by integrating computational methods with sensor network, embedded processors, human physical and mental activity recognition, and prosthetic control.

por.por_cntn:
The powered prosthesis is one of the typical cyber-physical systems (CPS) with human-in-the-loop. The human and prosthesis interaction is highly complicated; although the human user could learn to adjust the prosthesis, increased effort from the user will be required. The prosthesis should be tuned to minimize the user?s energy expenditure such that the user can use and interact with the prosthesis effortlessly and with comfort. Moreover, the amputee user and the prosthesis should have smooth cooperation to adapt to altered situations and environments. If the prosthesis can ?intelligently? understand the user?s volition and subsequently provide adaptive support to the user, the user will use and interact with the prosthesis more comfortably with less effort during gait owing to the reduced effort and load for the prosthesis manipulation and control. This brings a unique CPS challenge on the intelligent sensor technology to enable a robotic sense of the user?s volition. This project was implemented to meet the challenges of prosthesis optimization to minimize the user?s energy expenditure as well as the capacity of the prosthesis to adapt to dynamic situations and environments.

Intellectual Merits

Based on the low-power and high-speed wireless communication technology, this project has designed, developed, and validated ultra-wearable, wireless, synchronized, whole-body sensor networks including electroencephalography (EEG) on the scalp, functional near infra-red spectroscopy (fNIRS) on the head, electromyography (EMG) over the body, electrocardiography (ECG), inertia measurement unit for monitoring body motion, and insole ground reaction force (GRF) sensors. Based on the developed whole-body wireless sensor networks, this project has designed and validated a smart, data-driven parametric tuning method for optimizing powered prosthesis control. By optimizing machine learning methods, this project identified that the modified Nelder?Mead algorithm using a LatinHypercube Sampling method can greatly reduce the parametric tuning time compared with the conventional exhaustive method and genetic search method. This will largely reduce the time for the clinical prosthetic tuning. By using the whole-body sensor networks-based brain-computer interfacing technology, this project has designed and validated novel algorithms to recognize the amputee user?s intentions to initialize and terminate gait, change terrains, and stair up and down for adaptive control of the powered prosthesis. This project identified that with the incorporation of the support vector machine with wavelet feature extraction, reliable recognition of more than 90% accuracy was achieved as early as 1 second before the locomotion change. This enables a proactive parametric adaptation for the prosthetic control which may reduce the risk of falls and reduce energy compensation during amputee walking.

Broad Impact

More than one million people are living with lower-limb amputations in the United States. The sensor-based, personalized prosthesis optimization as well as the user?s control of a prosthesis to adapt to altered situations and environments will promote a natural gait and minimize an amputee?s energy expenditure when using the prosthesis. A prosthesis using optimized control technology developed in this project will increase equal force distribution and decrease the risk of damage to the intact limb from the musculoskeletal imbalance or pathologies. Maintenance of health in these areas is essential for the amputee?s quality of life and well-being. Two sensor network courses and two robotic courses have been developed from this project. These four courses are currently provided to both undergraduate and graduate students across the College of Engineering and Computing at FIU. This project also supported five Ph.D. students, and twelve master and undergraduate students in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering. The results from this project have been published in nineteen peer-reviewed articles and one issued patent. Furthermore, this project has been introduced in six media reports nationwide.
